issue.title: Unauthorized Objects in Arguments of GraphQL Input Objects Nullify Entire Mutation
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

When using `loads: Type` on arguments in GraphQL input objects, unauthorized objects will nullify the entire mutation field, rather than the just the one argument or input object.

**Versions**

`graphql` version: 2.0.15
`rails` version: 7.0.4

**GraphQL schema**

Sample schema:

```ruby
class Types::ProductType < GraphQL::Schema::Object
  field :id, ID, null: false

  def self.authorized?(object, context)
    false # treat all products as unauthorized for simplicity
  end
end

class Types::CartAddItemInputType < GraphQL::Schema::Object
  argument :product_id, ID, required: true, loads: Types::ProductType
  argument :quantity, Integer, required: true

  def self.load_product(product_id, context)
    ::Product.find(product_id) # Load an ActiveRecord model by ID
  end
end

class Mutations::CartAddItem < GraphQL::Schema::Mutation
  argument :input, Types::CartAddItemInputType, required: true

  field :success, Boolean, null: false

  def resolve(input:)
    { success: true } # this won't be reached
  end
end

class Types::MutationType < GraphQL::Schema::Object
  field :cart_add_item, mutation: Mutations::CartAddItem
end

class ApplicationSchema < GraphQL::Schema
  mutation MutationType

  def self.resolve_type(_type, object, _context)
    "Types::#{object.class.name}Type".constantize
  end
end
```

**GraphQL query**

Example GraphQL query and response (if query execution is involved)

```graphql
mutation {
  cartAddItem(input: {
    productId: 1,
    quantity:  1
  }) {
    success
  }
}
```

```json
{
  "data": {
    "cartAddItem": null
  }
}
```

The entire mutation field (`cartAddItem`) comes back as `null`, `Mutations::CartAddItem#resolve` is not called, and no errors are raised or returned.

**Steps to reproduce**

1. Define an input object with an argument that `loads:` a type
2. Define an authorization hook on the loaded type which return false

**Expected behavior**

In the above example, I would expect that `CartAddItemInput.product` argument would be nullified, and thereby an error would be thrown as the argument is marked required. (The issue occurs regardless of whether the argument is marked as required or not, however.)

**Actual behavior**

The mutation resolver is never called and the entire mutation field comes back as null.

comment.body: I ran into this today and would very much benefit from a `unauthorized_argument` hook.

commits.message: Add ISO8601Duration to Scalar guides page
Fix typo in comment in DurationEncodingError

Merge pull request #4688 from rubyroobs/rubyroobs/add-iso8601-duration

Add ISO8601Duration scalar type

pull_request.title: Add ISO8601Duration scalar type
pull_request.body:
## Changelog

* adds `ISO8601Duration` Scalar
  * raises `GraphQL::Error` when `ActiveSupport::Duration` is not defined
  * added reference in the `Scalar types` guide
* adds `DurationEncodingError` for when an improperly encoded duration is passed as an input
* add tests for `ISO8601Duration`

## Context

This adds support for ISO8601 durations for projects using Rails/ActiveSupport. Implements https://github.com/rmosolgo/graphql-ruby/pull/3637

Reimplemented what was done in https://github.com/rmosolgo/graphql-ruby/issues/3636 with the suggested changes/feedback from the previous PR taken into account.

issue.title: Dataloader: accept a limit on the number of fibers
issue.body:
Now, you could pass `fiber_limit:` to tell dataloader to use no more than the given number of fibers at once. 

(I got a bug report that `Fiber#resume` can fail with `FiberError: can't set a guard page: Cannot allocate memory` when Ruby runs up against a VM's `vm.max_map_count`. Besides increasing that limit, this option should put a cap on how many fibers are spun up at a time.) 

You can either pass default fiber limit: 

```ruby 
use GraphQL::Dataloader, fiber_limit: 10_000
```

or initialize a dataloader with a limit dynamically: 

```ruby 
context = { ... } 

if feature_flags[:dataloader_fiber_limit].enabled? # for example 
  # Assign a dataloader here to override the default configs:
  context[:dataloader] = GraphQL::Dataloader.new(fiber_limit: 10_000)
end

MySchema.execute(...) 
```

comment.body:
@rmosolgo I recently started getting this, dataloading probably 10k items across 5 different dataloaders.

dataloaders are using ActiveRecord, and I'm also using Puma.

issue.title: Thread.current[:__graphql_runtime_info] is nil in GraphQL::Schema::Field::ScopeExtension#after_resolve in field tests
issue.body:
_or_: is there a better way to test fields directly for permissions, that doesn't require writing a separate query for each one.

**Describe the bug**

Since updating from 2.0.26, we're seeing failures for lazy fields in tests, due to `Thread.current[:__graphql_runtime_info]` coming back with `nil` in `GraphQL::Schema::Field::ScopeExtension#after_resolve`. Non-lazy fields work fine.

**Versions**

`graphql` version: 2.1.3
`rails` (or other framework): 7.0.8
`graphql-batch`: 0.5.3

Hi, we currently  have a lot of field tests that test the Pundit permissions on fields, via GraphQL-pro.

We're testing like this, essentially:

```ruby
context = { current_user: User.first }
query = GraphQL::Query.new(MySchema, context: context)
instance = Types::PostType.authorized_new(Post.first, query.context)
field = Types::PostType.get_field('title')
arguments = {}
resolved = begin
  result = GraphQL::Batch.batch { field.resolve(instance, arguments, context) }

  # the failure is here on the .value call for `Lazy`s
  result.is_a?(GraphQL::Execution::Lazy) ? result.value : result
end
```

This allows us to switch around users, arguments, etc, in a way that doesn't require the labor of writing and maintaining actual queries for every single case.

The failure is the same error as #4672, but remains when using HEAD of `master`.

Is there a better way to test this? 

I'm currently just monkey-patching around this with a file in `spec/support`, by skipping the block.

```ruby
module GraphqlFieldAfterResolvePatch
  def after_resolve(object:, arguments:, context:, value:, memo:)
    return super if Thread.current[:__graphql_runtime_info]

    if value.nil?
      value
    else
      ret_type = @field.type.unwrap
      if ret_type.respond_to?(:scope_items)
        ret_type.scope_items(value, context)
      else
        value
      end
    end
  end
end

GraphQL::Schema::Field::ScopeExtension.prepend(GraphqlFieldAfterResolvePatch)
```

comment.body: I can't _always_ promise that GraphQL-Ruby's internals will work outside of GraphQL execution, but it was easy enough to maintain compatibility in this case 🍻

issue.title: Thread.current[:__graphql_runtime_info] is nil in GraphQL::Schema::Field::ScopeExtension#after_resolve in field tests
issue.body:
_or_: is there a better way to test fields directly for permissions, that doesn't require writing a separate query for each one.

**Describe the bug**

Since updating from 2.0.26, we're seeing failures for lazy fields in tests, due to `Thread.current[:__graphql_runtime_info]` coming back with `nil` in `GraphQL::Schema::Field::ScopeExtension#after_resolve`. Non-lazy fields work fine.

**Versions**

`graphql` version: 2.1.3
`rails` (or other framework): 7.0.8
`graphql-batch`: 0.5.3

Hi, we currently  have a lot of field tests that test the Pundit permissions on fields, via GraphQL-pro.

We're testing like this, essentially:

```ruby
context = { current_user: User.first }
query = GraphQL::Query.new(MySchema, context: context)
instance = Types::PostType.authorized_new(Post.first, query.context)
field = Types::PostType.get_field('title')
arguments = {}
resolved = begin
  result = GraphQL::Batch.batch { field.resolve(instance, arguments, context) }

  # the failure is here on the .value call for `Lazy`s
  result.is_a?(GraphQL::Execution::Lazy) ? result.value : result

```

This allows us to switch around users, arguments, etc, in a way that doesn't require the labor of writing and maintaining actual queries for every single case.

The failure is the same error as #4672, but remains when using HEAD of `master`.

Is there a better way to test this? 

I'm currently just monkey-patching around this with a file in `spec/support`, by skipping the block.

```ruby
module GraphqlFieldAfterResolvePatch
  def after_resolve(object:, arguments:, context:, value:, memo:)
    return super if Thread.current[:__graphql_runtime_info]

      ret_type = @field.type.unwrap

GraphQL::Schema::Field::ScopeExtension.prepend(GraphqlFieldAfterResolvePatch)
```

commits.message:
Merge pull request #4685 from rmosolgo/fix-scope-extension-runtime-dependency

Fix ScopeExtension outside of execution

Speed up `one_of?`

Speed up `one_of?` by defining it as `false`, and when `one_of` is used,
redefining the method as `true`.

In profiles, I noticed that `oneOf?` was taking _some_ time. Looping
through the directive list each time feels wasteful.

This approach borrows from Rails' `Class#class_attribute` and redefines
the `one_of?` when calling the `one_of` class method. This respects the
fact that directives are inherited from parent classes; so is the
`one_of?` class method. That said, this is not 100% backward compatible
because users could be adding the OneOf directive without using the
`one_of` DSL, but... it still feels pretty safe?

Merge pull request #4680 from jbourassa/faster-one-of-query

Speed up `one_of?`

pull_request.title: Speed up `one_of?`
pull_request.body:
Speed up `one_of?` by defining it as `false`, and when `one_of` is used, redefining the method as `true`.

In profiles, I noticed that `oneOf?` was taking _some_ time. Looping through the directive list each time feels wasteful.

This approach borrows from Rails' `Class#class_attribute` and redefines the `one_of?` when calling the `one_of` class method. This respects the fact that directives are inherited from parent classes; so is the `one_of?` class method. That said, **this is not 100% backward compatible** because users could be adding the OneOf directive without using the `one_of` DSL, but... it still feels pretty safe?


I didn't see a benchmark that had a lot of input, and in `rake bench:query`, the results are well within the margin of error. In a benchmark in our app though, where we're only validating a Hash against a GraphQL type, this made a difference.

issue.title: Speed up `one_of?`
issue.body:
Speed up `one_of?` by defining it as `false`, and when `one_of` is used, redefining the method as `true`.

In profiles, I noticed that `oneOf?` was taking _some_ time. Looping through the directive list each time feels wasteful.

This approach borrows from Rails' `Class#class_attribute` and redefines the `one_of?` when calling the `one_of` class method. This respects the fact that directives are inherited from parent classes; so is the `one_of?` class method. That said, **this is not 100% backward compatible** because users could be adding the OneOf directive without using the `one_of` DSL, but... it still feels pretty safe?


I didn't see a benchmark that had a lot of input, and in `rake bench:query`, the results are well within the margin of error. In a benchmark in our app though, where we're only validating a Hash against a GraphQL type, this made a difference.
